review.title: Conversational Markers of Constructive Discussions
review.abstract: Group discussions are essential for organizing every aspect of modern life, from faculty meetings to senate debates, from grant review panels to papal conclaves. While costly in terms of time and organization effort, group discussions are commonly seen as a way of reaching better decisions compared to solutions that do not require coordination between the individuals (e.g. voting)---through discussion, the sum becomes greater than the parts. However, this assumption is not irrefutable: anecdotal evidence of wasteful discussions abounds, and in our own experiments we find that over 30% of discussions are unproductive.

metadata.title: Conversational Markers of Constructive Discussions

sections.text: Group discussions are indispensable for organizing all aspects of modern life, from faculty meetings to Senate debates, from exam boards to papal conclaves. Although they are time-consuming and organizational, group discussions are commonly seen as a way to make better decisions than solutions that do not require coordination between individuals (e.g. voting) - discussions add up to more than the parts. However, this assumption is not irrefutable: there is abundant anecdotal evidence of wasteful discussions, and in our own experiments we find that over 30% of discussions are unproductive. We propose a framework for analyzing the dynamics of conversations to determine whether a particular task-oriented discussion is worthwhile or not. We use conversation patterns that reflect the flow of ideas and balance between participants, as well as their linguistic choices. We apply this framework to conversations that naturally take place in an online collaborative world-exploration game that is developed and used to support this research.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Working in teams is a common decision-making and problem-solving strategy, as it can build on effective social interaction and each member's ability to outdo individuals. Evidence shows that teams often outperform individuals (Williams and Sternberg, 1988) and even have a high chance of achieving correct responses when all team members have been wrong before (Laughlin and Adamopoulos, 1980). Moreover, team performance is not always a factor of individual intelligence, but collective intelligence (Woolley et al., 2010), with interpersonal interactions and emotional intelligence playing an important role (Jordan et al., 2002). However, as most people can attest from experience, team interaction is not always smooth, and poor coordination can lead to unproductive meetings and wasted time. In fact, Romano Jr and Nunamaker Jr. (2001) report that a third of work-related meetings in the U.S. are considered unproductive, while a Microsoft employee survey reports that 69% of meetings are ineffective.

sections.heading: 7.1 Experimental setup
sections.text: So far, we have characterized the relationship between a team's interaction patterns and its productivity level, which opens the door to detecting constructive and non-constructive interactions in realistic environments where the true answer is not known. Ideally, such an automatic system could prompt unproductive teams to rethink their approach or instead aggregate their individual responses. Early detection could stop non-constructive discussions or put them on the right track. To assess the feasibility of such a challenging task and compare the predictive power of our characteristics, we consider three classification goals: (+): The team outperforms its best member (cbest > 0)? (+): The team is constructive (cavg > 0)? (-): The team outperforms its worst member (cworst < 0)? To investigate early detection, we evaluate the classification performance when we measure data only from the first 20 seconds of interaction.11 Measured from the first message or message.

sections.text: We compare a baseline, which consists of team size, average number of messages per player, and conversation duration. For comparison, we refer to features of the flow of ideas and interaction dynamics (Section 6.2) as interaction, and linguistic and lexical features (Section 6.3) as linguistics. The combination model, which includes fundamentals, interaction, linguistic and linguistic n-gram features, is consistently the best and significantly exceeds random guessing (AUC.50) in almost all settings. Although the overall results are modest, the results confirm that our framework of conversation analysis has predictive power and that the challenging task of early prediction is feasible. sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We have developed a framework based on conversation dynamics to distinguish between productive and unproductive task-oriented discussions. By applying it to an online community game we designed for this study, we reveal new interactions with conversation patterns. Constructive teams tend to be well-balanced in several ways, with team members equally involved in ideas and guesses and showing little asymmetry in language matching. Also, the flow of ideas between team mates features predictive linguistic cues, with the most constructive teams using fewer hedges when introducing and adopting ideas. We show that such cues have predictive power even when they are extracted from the first 20 seconds of conversations. In future work, improved classifiers could lead to a system that can intervene early in non-constructive discussions, track them down and avoid wasted time. Further improvement in classification performance on such a difficult task will depend on better conversation processing tools, which are robust for the game and, in particular, for the domain design of ideas.

metadata.abstractText: Group discussions are essential for organizing every aspect of modern life, from faculty meetings to senate debates, from grant review panels to papal conclaves. While costly in terms of time and organization effort, group discussions are commonly seen as a way of reaching better decisions compared to solutions that do not require coordination between the individuals (e.g. voting)—through discussion, the sum becomes greater than the parts. However, this assumption is not irrefutable: anecdotal evidence of wasteful discussions abounds, and in our own experiments we find that over 30% of discussions are unproductive. We propose a framework for analyzing conversational dynamics in order to determine whether a given task-oriented discussion is worth having or not. We exploit conversational patterns reflecting the flow of ideas and the balance between the participants, as well as their linguistic choices. We apply this framework to conversations naturally occurring in an online collaborative world exploration game developed and deployed to support this research. Using this setting, we show that linguistic cues and conversational patterns extracted from the first 20 seconds of a team discussion are predictive of whether it will be a wasteful or a productive one.
